statement.tex: \text{Show that the function }f(x) = \vert x - 3\vert, x\in\mathbb{R} \\ \text{is continuous but not differentiable at } x = 3.

reason.tex: \text{For a function to be continuous at a}\\ \text{point A, two conditions must be satisfied.} \\ \text{First, the function must converge to the}\\ \text{same value from either side of A.}\\ \qquad \lim_{x\to A^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to A^+}f(x) \\ \text{And this limit must equal the value of the}\\ \text{function at that point} \\ \qquad \lim_{x\to A}f(x) = f(A)

f(x)\text{ is defined at }A=(3,0). \\ \text{But if it has to be differentiable (have a rate}\\ \text{of change), then} \\ \begin{align} \left[\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\right]_{x\to 3^-} &= \left[\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\right]_{x\to 3^+}\\ \text{But }\left[\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\right]_{x\to 3^-} &= \dfrac{d}{dx}(3-x) = -1 \\ \text{and }\left[\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\right]_{x\to 3^+} &= \dfrac{d}{dx}(x-3) = 1 \end{align} \\ \text{Hence, }f(x)\text{ is not differentiable at }A= (3,0).\\ \text{You can see the same from the graph in Step 1.}
